sect1.title: &obsa; Components
sect1.para: The &obsa; is not a monolithic server: It consists of multiple daemons that perform different tasks.

sect2.title: Front-end
sect2.para: The &obsa; front-end is a Ruby on Rails application that manages access to and manipulation of &obsa; data. It provides a Web user interface and an application programming interface (API) to do so. Both can be used to create, read, update and delete users, projects, packages, requests and other objects. It also implements additional sub-systems like authentication, search, and email notifications.

sect2.title: Back-end
sect2.para: The &obsa; back-end is a collection of Perl applications that manage the source files and build jobs of the &obsa;.

sect3.title: Source Server
sect3.para: Maintains the source repository and project/package configurations. It provides an HTTP interface, which is the only interface to the Front-end. It may forward requests to other back-end services. Each &obsa; installation has exactly one Source Server. It maintains the sources, trees and projects directories.

sect3.title: Repository Server
sect3.para: A repository server provides access to the binaries via an HTTP interface. It is used by the front-end via the source server only. Workers use the server to register, request the binaries needed for build jobs, and store the results. Notifications for schedulers are also created by repository servers. Each &obsa; installation has at least one repository server. A larger installation using partitioning has one on each partition.

sect3.title: Scheduler
sect3.para: A scheduler calculates the need for build jobs. It detects changes in sources, project configurations or in binaries used in the build environment. It is responsible for starting jobs in the right order and integrating the built binary packages. Each &obsa; installation has one scheduler per available architecture and partition. It maintains the build directory.

sect3.title: Dispatcher
sect3.para: The dispatcher takes a job (created by the scheduler) and assigns it to a free worker. It also checks possible build constraints to verify that the worker qualifies for the job. It only notifies a worker about a job; the worker itself downloads the required resources. Each &obsa; installation has one dispatcher per partition (one of which is the master dispatcher).

sect3.title: Publisher
sect3.para: The publisher processes "publish" events from the scheduler for finished repositories. It merges the build result of all architectures into a defined directory structure, creates the required metadata, and optionally syncs it to a download server. It maintains the "repos" directory on the back-end. Each &obsa; installation has one publisher per partition.

sect3.title: Worker
sect3.para: The workers register with the repository servers. They receive build jobs from the dispatcher. Afterwards they download sources from source server and the required binaries from the repository server(s). They build the package using the build script and send the results back to the repository server. A worker can run on the same host as other services, but most &obsa; installations have dedicated hardware for the workers.

sect3.title: Signer
sect3.para: The signer handles signing events and calls an external tool to execute the signing. Each &obsa; installation usually has one signer per partition and one on the source server installation.

sect3.title: Warden
sect3.para: The warden monitors the workers and detects crashed or hanging workers. Their build jobs will be canceled and restarted on another host. Each &obsa; installation can have one Warden service running on each partition.

sect3.title: Download on Demand Updater (dodup)
sect3.para: The download on demand updater monitors all external repositories which are defined as "download on demand" resources. It polls for changes in the metadata and re-downloads the metadata as needed. The scheduler will be notified to recalculate the build jobs depending on these repositories afterwards. Each &obsa; installation can have one dodup service running on each partition.

sect3.title: Delta Store
sect3.para: The delta store daemon maintains the deltas in the source storage. Multiple obscpio archives can be stored in one deltastore to avoid duplication on disk. This service calculates the delta and maintains the delta store. Each &obsa; installation can have one delta store process running next to the source server.

sect2.title: Command Line Client
sect2.para: The Open Build Service Commander (osc) is a Python application with a Subversion-style command-line interface. It can be used to manipulate or query data from the &obsa; through its application programming interface.

sect2.title: Content Delivery Server
sect2.para: &obsa; is agnostic about how you serve build results to your users. It will just write repositories to disk. But many people sync these repositories to some content delivery system like MirrorBrain.

sect2.title: Requirements
sect2.para: We highly recommend, and in fact only test, installations on the SUSE Linux Enterprise Server and openSUSE operating systems. However, there also are installations on Debian and Fedora systems.
The &obsa; also needs a SQL database (MySQL or MariaDB) for persistent and a memcache daemon for volatile data.
